required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Effects of Alcohol Use on Chronic Orofacial Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Effects of Alcohol Use on Chronic Orofacial Pain

collaborator.agency: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA)

brief_summary.textblock: Self-medication of pain with alcohol is a common, yet risky, behavior among individuals with chronic orofacial pain. Chronic pain status may affect the degree to which alcohol use relieves pain, but the independent contributions of pain chronification and alcohol-related expectations and conditioning have not been previously studied. This project addresses this gap in knowledge and will inform further research and clinical/translational efforts for reducing risk associated with these behaviors.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: People with and without temporomandibular joint and muscle disorder (TMD) will receive an active oral dose of alcohol or placebo in a counterbalanced manner.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1; Day 2 (Laboratory sessions will be separated by at least 48 hours.)
primary_outcome.description: Pressure applied at insertion of the masseter at which participant reports pain. VAS (visual analogue scale) pain intensity and unpleasantness ratings anchored from "no pain at all"/"not at all unpleasant" to "most intense/unpleasant imaginable" will be collected.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Pressure Pain Intensity - 4 fpsi
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1; Day 2 (Laboratory sessions will be separated by at least 48 hours.)
primary_outcome.description: Pain ratings associated with 6 foot pounds per square inch (fpsi) of pressure applied to the insertion of the masseter. VAS (visual analogue scale) pain intensity and unpleasantness ratings anchored from "no pain at all"/"not at all unpleasant" to "most intense/unpleasant imaginable" will be collected.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Pressure Pain Intensity - 5 fpsi
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1; Day 2 (Laboratory sessions will be separated by at least 48 hours.)
primary_outcome.description: Pain ratings associated with 7 foot pounds per square inch (fpsi) of pressure applied to the insertion of the masseter. VAS (visual analogue scale) pain intensity and unpleasantness ratings anchored from "no pain at all"/"not at all unpleasant" to "most intense/unpleasant imaginable" will be collected.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Pressure Pain Intensity - 6 fpsi
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1; Day 2 (Laboratory sessions will be separated by at least 48 hours.)
primary_outcome.description: Pain ratings associated with 8 foot pounds per square inch (fpsi) of pressure applied to the insertion of the masseter. VAS (visual analogue scale) pain intensity and unpleasantness ratings anchored from "no pain at all"/"not at all unpleasant" to "most intense/unpleasant imaginable" will be collected.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1; Day 2 (Laboratory sessions will be separated by at least 48 hours.)
primary_outcome.description: Rating of relief from pain associated with consumption of the study beverage. VAS (visual analogue scale) assessing perceived relief anchored from "No relief at all" to "Most profound relief imaginable".

arm_group.description: Individuals seeking care for temporomandibular joint and muscle disorder (TMD).
Healthy social drinkers without TMD recruited as a comparison group.

intervention.description: A beverage containing dose of ethanol individually determined to raise a participant's breath alcohol concentration up to approximately 0.08 g/dL.
A beverage that does not meaningfully increase breath alcohol concentration.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Positive diagnosis of temporomandibular joint and muscle disorder (TMD) (TMD group only)
- Consume at least 1 drink/month over the past 6 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of chronic pain other than TMD
- Current use of opioids
- Current major depression
- History of any psychotic disorder
- Undercontrolled hypertension or diabetes
- History of neurologic disease
- History of serious medical illness
- History of drug or alcohol dependence, including nicotine, or a pattern of hazardous alcohol use

facility.name: Center for Pain Research and Behavioral Health at UF Health
